Good morning,

1Samuel 17:1-58, “Then he took his staff in his hand; and chose for himself give smooth stones from the brook…”

Would like to share devotion series I shared back in 2003. It ministered to me and I hope it does minister to you for the first time or for the second time. Be blessed.

I have heard and come across people with hidden potentials yet to be discovered. In the entertainment industry we hear about people being discovered because of their talents. I have heard stories of humble beginning. Often times you hear about a struggle from the beginning especially with rejections and words spoken that they were not good enough but later they broke through.

Everyone desires a chance to be able to show what they have within, their talents, abilities, skills, performance, products. A chance to be a boss, husband, wife, teacher, worker, grand parents etc. Very few people are interested in being paid to keep quite as most people will always cry, “give me a chance to show what I can do”. Don’t we see this in the work force? people who see new positions that they may not have all the qualifications needed but they believe in themselves that given a chance, they can do it. A belief that you can offer something and make a difference can push you to desire a chance. Our chance as believers is not to show off, but make God look big in the eyes of men. He is already big let’s not forget that, but for the people in the world, we need to show them how Big Our God is. 2Chronoicles 16:9, “For the eyes of the Lord run to and fro throughout the whole earth, to show Himself so strong on behalf of those whose hearts are loyal to Him”. He has given us a chance to show Him so strong.

There is a big difference between knowing what to do…and doing what you know. Most people know what to do but they cannot propel and believe in themselves that they can do it. They have potentials hidden.  David and Goliath is a story that reveals some things that are vital in our lives. We know David’s position, he is a shepherd boy, taking care of sheep and smells like one. Though young, he is good at what he is does, he is faithful in his job. An opportunity rises when his father sends him to the battleground to bring food to his brothers. Again we see that he is also obedient in the sense that he does what he’s been asked to do. I’m not sure whether he loved to take care of the sheep when his brothers were soldiers in the army but I do know that he knew his job pretty well. He was faithful and obedient in doing so. You may not like what you do, but can you be still good at it, faithful and obedient while trusting God to elevate you in due time?. I believe God sees our attitude in what we do and if we cannot be content first with where we are, we will not be content when we move because before long…you know the rest. Anyway, David has a chance to be all he can be while still attending to the sheep.

1Samuel 17:20, “So David rose in early in the morning… and took the things and went as Jesse (his father) had commanded him”, I say boldly that God was setting this young man up. He does not know what awaits him, maybe he never saw himself beyond being a shepherd boy but his obedient leads him to serve his superiors (his brothers) without murmuring and complaining. Now David coming to the grounds finds that the enemies are not fighting each other, he has just left what he brought with the supply keeper, runs to the battle ground to greet his brothers and in the process of time, he hears about Goliath sending threats to the Israelites. David has just learnt that no one including the king has the capability of facing this giant. They rehearse to him what will happen to any man who can kill Goliath. It’s like hearing, a job description and the benefits. The job is to kill Goliath, benefits are great riches, a hand of king’s daughter in marriage and exemption from taxes. What an opportunity, who is he? what chance does he have?. We’ll tackle more on it tomorrow. Have a blessed morning, Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

John 5:1-15, “…Sir I have no man to put me into the pool when the water is stirred up…”

Now a certain man who had infirmity for 38years happened to be at a pool introduced to us in the story. Besides him, there were so many people who had different issues in their lives that caused them to be the outcast of the society. The pool of Bethesda was a pool where many people with different kind of sickness were brought to and once a year, an angel of God would come down and stir the water and whoever jumped in first was healed of any kind of sickness they had. The man who is most talked about in the story had been sick for 38 years and I bet that the moment he became sick, they brought him to the pool but every year he missed jumping into the pull. I know that friends who had been with him and for him in the beginning after some time gave up on him and he kind of gotten used to being the same way and being in the same place.

Isn’t amazing that we all go through and deal with different things that leave us impotent, handicapped, paralyzed, lame and broken. The things we need to do, we don’t do because of our nature and situations. At times we are looking for help and when we think we got it, something jumps a head of us and we miss it and now we have to wait for another cycle because we don’t see how it can happen again soon. Before you know it, you give up trying like the man and you seat by the pool of Bethesda just watching people get healed. Then thoughts linger in your mind that the victory is not for you because you have not strength to move from point A to point B. Every time you try to rise, you fall back to the same place because your legs that ought to function are impotent. Every time something good is about to happen, someone says something that gets into your nerve causing you to forfeit your opportunity for victory.

You may have strengths and victories in many areas but there is that part that does not function well. I still struggle with many things that at times I wonder whether I will jump on time and not forfeit.  One day after many years Jesus shows up during a Passover feast. Remember that it’s a feast, everyone is supposed to have a good time but some people somewhere are nursing their failures by the pool of Bethesda. I would imagine Jesus seating with everyone to feast but He goes to the pool to minister to people. Thank God that when I cannot get to Him, He can get to me. He comes down and He knows that this man had been in terrible condition and asks him “…do you want to be made well?… I believe that in as much as this man was sick, He needed to ask him for some people don’t want to get out of their situations as they are looking for sympathy and special help. He’s reply, “…Sir I have no man…”. He cares for me that He will come to my rescue and when I have tried programs and methods of getting delivered from my struggles, He shows up asking me the same question, “do you want to be well, victorious, free, strong, move forward? Jesus tells the man to pick up his bed and go home. Imagine carrying the thing which has been carrying you for many years. Walking on top of what you were once sinking in. What is that thing that has caused you to be impotent, handicapped, paralyzed, lame and broken, it could be jealousy, hatred, unforgiveness, lust, pride, stinginess and more and you desired to be free from them and so you tried to free yourself through different methods but still failed. It’s like this man who every time tried to jump but missed it. It’s not by might, nor by power but by my Sprit says the Lord. Thank God He has come at the right time asking me the same question and my answer is , “It’s not my will to be like this, want to be made well (free)”.

title.rendered: What You Have Is What You Need

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Exodus 4:1-5, “…So the Lord said to him, “What is that in your hand?” He said, “A rod””

Everyone can be used of God because God has placed in you something to offer. You may not know what it is but it’s there. We all have different gifts and talents and that makes Christianity exciting. There is something about being together in unity that paves away for gifts and talents to be realized. God allows us to have different measures of gifts that when shared, our growth increases. The bible says that we collectively are like a human body that has hands, legs, head etc. They are all working together and can function but not fully without the help of the other. The leg cannot tell the hands “I don’t need you” neither can the mouth tell the eyes that it doesn’t need it. They all have different functions but they all work together. Psalm 133:1, “Behold how good and pleasant it is for brethren to dwell together in unity”

God calls Moses for a task and the first thing that God tells Moses that He will be used to deliver the children of Israel out of bondage. He is scared to death and we know why, he had killed an Egyptian and ran away. He was safe and peaceful where he was. Then here comes God telling him that He will send him back from where he came from. Remember that Moses was a prince in the land of Egypt at one time and then later refused to be one when he discovered he was not an Egyptian. A onetime prince becomes a killer then a fugitive and here comes God sending him back to where he killed. I believe that at one point in life God will send some people to places they came from, not to be part of it again but to be a deliverer to them that perish. When God does send you back to deliver them, you will not go under your own strength or power but His.

It’s not easy to go back to where you have come from when everyone there already knows your history especially when you messed up big time. You are not sure as to whether they will listen to what you have to say or not, but when God  sends you, signs and wonders will a company you if you believe. How often times do we talk to God about what we think is going to happen, how we will fail and yet He is telling us to just believe. God goes as far as demonstrating  what he will do and the question Moses is asked is, “What is that in your hand?” He said, “A rod”. A rod? what’s up with the rod? Is this is the means the Lord will use to deliver His people?. God is the source and He has chosen to use the things that we have as the means to get the job done. When there is something in your life that you do not think the Lord will use, that is exact thing He will use. Be it your voice, smile, words of encouragement, little help, giving, being there for someone who needs help, a touch, prayers. To you it maybe small and insignificant but to God it is something that He can use. Don’t you ever loose the rod you have in your hand thinking it’s nothing, what you have can work wonders in someone’s life and when you know how to use it, let no one cause you to forfeit by telling you that it’s not necessary, if it’s working for you, you got to stick with what is working for you. In fact you ought to be the best in it. You may never know the impact you will be making as you use the rod in your hands. Moses delivered the children of Israel using the same rod which was considered the rod of a shepherd. Pharaoh had a mighty powerful army, God did not sent Moses with a backing army. He sent him with a rod of a shepherd and His presence.

If you’ve been waiting for something bigger than what you have before being used, I’ve got news for you, “What you have is what you need”, your faithfulness in small things will open new channels for greater things. Be blessed

Thanks
Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Can you imagine having a job of tasting wine for a king?  This was
actually a very high profile job in biblical times.  The cupbearer was
one who tasted and served wine to the king. Ancient kings had to be
very cautious about what they ate and drank. They used trusted
servants to taste everything before they consumed it. If the servant
lived or did not get sick, the king and queen then ate or drank. The
“chief butler” in the Joseph account (Genesis 40) headed the king’s
cupbearers. Nehemiah held this highly trusted position under King
Artaxerxes (Neh. 1:11), influencing the king politically. King Solomon
also employed cupbearers (1 Kin. 10:5).  In modern times there are
tests scientists and pharmacists can run to discover if something
contains poison.  One man had sole responsibility of being the one to
test if the king’s wine was poisonous or palatable.  This was a
position of great trust I would imagine as the cupbearer may be killed
in the service of the king.  I am sure there were conspirators who
attempted to take the life of the king through poisoning the wine.
The trusted cupbearer would be the one to discover the true contents
of the wine even at the cost of his very life.  The cupbearer then was
a high court official, one that was close to the king and having the
trust of the king.  The cupbearer would also sit at the right hand of
the king.  The cupbearer had to have the king’s best interest in mind,
and not his own.  This would be likened to the President’s bodyguard.
The bodyguard, the cupbearer, may have to give his life for the sake
of the king.
 
At the Last Supper, Jesus took the cup and said, “…Take this cup and
drink from it all of you.  This is the cup of the New Covenant, which
is shed for you and for all.”

In the Garden of Gethsemane Jesus said, (Matt 22:40-46 pp-;Mt
26:36-46; Mk 14:32-42)  Father, if you are willing, take this cup from
me; yet not my will, but yours be done.”  Please meditate on this in
you’re mind and spirit.  Jesus Christ was ultimate cupbearer and yet
the King simultaneously.  The cupbearers throughout the Scriptures sat
in the high, noble, and trustworthy position at the right hand of the
king and placed their lives on the line for the King.  Here in the New
Testament Jesus Christ is the cupbearer that places His life on the
line as the King of Kings (in His humanity) that God’s wrath might not
come upon you and I.  Christ submitted to the will of His father and
now sits at the right hand of His Father.
Jesus was reminding the disciples that He would soon fulfill the
ultimate role of the cupbearer.

This is why Paul makes such a big deal about the manner in which one
takes communion.  The cupbearer Jesus Christ, willingly, lay his life
down for you (see 1 Cor. 11: 27 – 33), lest one dare partake in His
sacrifice in an unworthy manner.  When you partake in communion
realize that in doing so it is not just some religious ritual, but a
remembrance of what Christ did in the past, is doing in the present,
and will do in the future, because He is the same yesterday, today,
and forever.

Thank the Lord today, and daily for even having the opportunity to
partake in communion together.  Blessings by Pastor Phil

Good morning,

James 1:19, “Understand, my beloved brethren. Let every man be quick to hear (a ready listener), slow to speak, slow to take offense and to get angry” (AMP)

Words that come out of our mouths are very powerful. They either do good or do damage. I think words can really cut deep and may take long time to heal compared to a natural deep cut. I have said some things that I did not mean to or came out the wrong way and I wish I could take them back cause they did such a great damage. Isn’t it amazing that God created only one mouth and two ears which would indicate we need to listen more than actually speak? If it wasn’t for my mouth, I would have gotten myself into less trouble.

James encourages believers by saying, “Let every man be quick to hear (ready to listen)” first. Even the judge before he delivers a verdict first listens to the case. Listening lets you process what goes in, then applying  wisdom as to how it will come out. Those who are quick to speak lack the wisdom that is required to process what will come out of the mouth. You know of those times things came out of your mouth you wished you took time to process in your mind before speaking them out. One of the barriers to communication in marriages is, couples tend to be quick to speak and slow to listen when it should be the other way round. What happens is that our mouths are loaded with words ready to fire. We want our points to come across first and therefore what is being said is not being taken in to be processed and brought out in wisdom. Under pressure we speak words we don’t mean and once they are fired, they cannot come back. We can also do this with our kids. There are parents who just want to tell their kids what they must do neglecting the opportunity to listen to what their kids have to say. Some have belittled their kids by what they say to them. The kids should get their definition from home. Mom and dad who are raising them are the ones to affirm them. Listening may not mean you do what they say but giving them a place to air their voices, this would also let you know which areas they are growing in and which areas you need to help them develop. Parents say, “kids don’t listen”, and now kids are saying, “parents don’t listen”. Listening is hard but vital.

Then James says, “slow to speak”, The order of things, “quick to listen” then “slow to speak”. This is not talking about speaking slowly but being careful about what you say and how you say it. This does require wisdom for in the process of being hasty to speak, corrupted words may be close. Proverbs 10:19, says, “In the multitude of words sin is not lacking, But he who restrains his lips is wise”. There is safety in listening than speaking.

If we become great listeners and slow to speak, I wouldn’t be surprised if offenses and being angry were minimized because of the order of things. Listening shows you value what someone has to say and without listening, we will continue to battle without great solutions. Be quick to listen and slow to speak, you could save yourself a lot of heartache.

Thanks
Evans

Good morning,

Genesis 3:13, Vs. 1 “the serpent (devil) was more cunning than any beast of the field which the Lord God had made”

Vs. 1 “begins by saying, “the serpent (devil) was more cunning than any beast of the field which the Lord God had made”. He is the greatest deceiver that has ever lived and we know his mission from John 10:10, “The thief commetth not but for to kill, steal and destroy”. Those have been his greatest tools not forgetting another major one deception. Being that he is cunning, he goes for his tricks, which will lead to deception, kill, steal and destroy. He is very smart and he knows how to play his cards well. Eve becomes the first victim to be deceived into doing what was not acceptable to God by listening to the serpent and taking the fruit and eating it. He knows that if he can get one, he will get many for man has a way of destroying others too. The fruit was not bad looking vs. 6. “so when the woman saw that the tree was good for food, that it was pleasant to the eyes, and desirable to make one wise, she took of it’s fruit and ate it”. Question, where was Adam when all this were happening, He is to be the priest of the field, giving directions and leading, he is to tend to the garden and have dominion over all the things God created. Well the woman eats the fruit and offers Adam who does not resist and immediately their eyes opened. In line of the story, we see it even today, people who have been deceived may want companion and that would mean deceiving someone else. I have heard this phrase, “If I go down, I’m taking you with me”, I will blow your cover, I will use something I know about you to bring you down for it’s not right for you to stand strong while I am dealing with this”. Been in a position where some one tried to make your life miserable because they could not stand being miserable themselves?

The moment deception is activated and one’s eyes are opened, it robs them of the dignity they had. It also robs them of confidence and ability to stand as guilt and shame get on the drivers seat to take over. vs. 12&13, “The man said, “the woman whom You gave to be with me, she gave me of the tree, and I ate”, And the Lord said to the woman, “what is this you have done?”. The woman said, “The serpent deceived me, and I ate”. One of the destroyer of people is not deception even though deception is lethal but not willing to take responsibility for their actions. The bible says that, “He who covers his sins will not prosper”. This is what I call shifting blames, instead of people taking responsibility for what they have done, they blame it on someone else. She tricked me, he betrayed me, she used me, he made me do it. Instead of Adam confessing his failure and asking for forgiveness and maybe God forgiving him, he is blaming it on Eve and Eve blames it on the serpent. You cannot expect healing by shifting blames on someone else. God is to wise to allow someone else destiny to be determined by someone else actions. When David committed adultery with Bathsheba, he did not go around blaming where he was standing or how the woman might have been bathing out there on purpose to make him fall, no, he said “it’s me Lord who has a problem and against thee have I sinned” Psalm 51, “create in me a clean heart and renew a right spirit within me”. Have you been blaming everything and everyone for where you are? The process of healing is admitting that you have failed and asking the Lord to help you with your weakness and failures.

Thanks

Good morning,

Luke 19:1-10, “…Zacchaeus, make haste and come down, for today I must stay at house”

The devo is a little bit long but worth reading!!

It is very essential to be in a position to commune with God every day. There are special times we need to put aside and call on God. The times we are living in, only prayers to our God will save us. Do you know that there are so many things that could be avoided if people were praying? I don’t want to pray when it has happened but I want to pray before it happens for prayer paves a way for God to move. If you are not praying, you are missing out one of the greatest opportunities to meet God.

In our text this morning, Jesus is on His way to Jerusalem passing through Jericho. One thing I love about Jesus is that I don’t see Him making schedules as to what to do on any particular day, who to heal, who to speak with, I just here Him moving, changing, touching, delivering, healing and doing things without appointments for He was under divine appointment partially because the bible says in Acts 10:38, “How God anointed Jesus Christ of Nazareth who went about doing good unto the children of men”. Everywhere He went, all He was doing was good. On the mission to reach someone, anyone who stopped Him for a miracle, He served all.

Romans 10:13, “For whoever calls upon the name of the Lord shall be saved”. We have an awesome opportunity to call, what are we going to do? Zacchaeus is a chief tax collector, he is rich but of short stature. During then, the tax collectors were known to rip people off. I read  that Zacchaeus was a Jew but he was collecting taxes for the Romans. Being of short stature and cunning, this might have made the Jews dislike him therefore he might have thought, “I will get rich and maybe people will respect me”. When he got rich, still much wasn’t changing and he must have been getting frustrated. I wouldn’t be surprised if depression creped in, fear, insecurity and the like for we are not told that he was happy even in his riches. One thing we know about when he heard that Jesus was in town, he desired to see Jesus vs. 3 , “And he sought to see who Jesus was”, He sought which in other words mean trying to find, asking questions, looking around by all means that he would see who Jesus was. The crowd was blocking him from seeing Him but he was determined to see Jesus. Mat 6:33, “Seek ye first the kingdom of God and His righteousness”, we got to be a people who are willing to seek the kingdom of God first, yes we have our own strengths and abilities but behind those also lies deception, confusion and fear and just like Zacchaeus knowing all about himself and his failures and partly his success, he desires to see this Man that everyone followed created a thirst. He must have heard that Jesus healed the sick, raised the dead, did wonderful things but what would Zacchaeus really need to see Jesus for? he wasn’t sick in the body and he wasn’t going to make extra money if he saw Him, there must have been emptiness in him that he needed someone to fill and so he sought. There are certain blessings, healings, restorations that will not appear until we seek diligently and that takes time, prayer, effort, patience, trust, confidence in God.

Situations and people can discourage you from seeking God. People blocked his view, and no one cared enough to give him space to see Jesus. Everyone minded their own business and may I say that though many saw Jesus, most of them were not as hungry as Zacchaeus. Desperate people take desperate measures, they will pray desperate prayers for they are certain that only God is their source of hope and if He does not show up, that will be the end of them. I thank God because He has allowed me to seek Him that I may find Him, to call on Him that He may answer me, to knock at His door that He may open. There will be obstacles but we got to keep doing what we know.

Vs. 4, “So he ran a head and climbed up into a sycamore tree to see Him, for He was going to pass that way”. Here is a man who is seizing the moment for this opportunity can pass him by and he refuses to allow it to pass him by. I know of the times I went to pray before God and there were so many hindrances for the flesh tried to stop me from praying but I would still fight hard for I knew God was going to give me a breakthrough so I climbed a tree of praise. You begin to praise God in your hindrances, you will climb a spiritual tree bringing you closer and closer to Him where He can recognize you. God inhabits the praises of His people. If you struggle to be able to lock in, include worship and praises in your prayers and you will see how you will climb a spiritual tree higher than the things that wants to stop you.

Vs. 5, “And when Jesus came to the place, He looked up and saw him, and said to him, Zacchaeus, make haste and come down, for today I must stay at house”. I’m glad that in spite of everything, He has seen me and my God He knows my name. This is what I would call going past the gates of praise into His sanctuary where it’s one on one. Psalms 9:10, “And they that know thy name will put their trust in thee; for thou oh Lord, hast not forsaken them that seek thee”. Not only does He see him, He calls him by his name, and then tells him to come down for today Jesus would be his guest. He has stolen the show without knowing but not for wrong motives or selfish ambitions but for a change, 1John 3:2, “… and when He shall appear, we shall be like Him for we shall see Him as He is”.

Vs6&7, “So he made haste and came down, and received Him joyfully, but when they saw it, they all complained saying, “He has gone to be a guest with a man who is a sinner”. For the first time someone accepted Zacchaeus for who he is without judging him, he is grateful and so are we that when no one else could accept us the way we were, our desire to know Him caused us to be noticed by Him and offered to be under our roofs. I thank God for the times I have been able to call on Him for those were the times He revealed Himself so strong, the times when I felt that He could have had better things to do when I stopped Him, through my desire to see Him and then going extra mile to climb higher through worship and prayers, He took notice of me. 1John 1:4, “Ye are of God ye little children, for you have overcome them (obstacles), for greater is He that lives inside of you, than He that lives in the world”

As you read the rest of the portion of scriptures, as Jesus was in his house, Zacchaeus was convicted and began to change his ways of living, transformed by the renewing of his mind and the best thing he received, salvation. Vs 9, “today salvation has come to this house”. What is hindering you from seeing and meeting Jesus today and always? When was the last time you felt His presence? Are you worshipping and praying like you should? Do something about your situation for there is a divine appointment.

Thanks
Evans

Good morning,

James 2:14-26, vs. 24, You see then that a man is JUSTIFIED by works, and not by faith only. vs. “For as the body without the spirit is dead, so FAITH without WORKS is dead also..”

As I continue to read, I discover more how James did not write an evangelistic message, rather his exhortation is addressed to the believers. As soon as the gospel has been received by faith in Christ alone for salvation, the Christian life has to be lived. Someone said, “It’s faith alone that justifies, but the faith that justifies can never be alone” Another interesting thought, “Good works are such that a man is neither justified by them or without them”. Let me stress this point one more time before I move on, we are not saved by works but by faith alone and now that we are saved, our life of faith is demonstrated by works. So when I read James, I learn that he is not teaching me about FAITH PLUS WORKS, he is teaching me about FAITH AT WORK. Can I now say boldly that it’s impossible to show faith without works? For me yes, not sure about you.

This principal has worked personally in my life as a Christian. When I came to work for this company, God did not tell me to come and work here, I knew what was acceptable according to His word and I acted on it by faith trusting His leading and guidance. That if it was not His will, then the door would be shut. I had faith, I put that faith to work by making phone calls, going for interviews, taking qualifying tests and here I am today. God blessed me. This was a clear indication of faith at work for something that was way bigger than me. I had the opportunity to sit and pray and pray by faith for God to move but I had to learn that God needs something in my life to work with. Proverbs 18:22, “He who finds a wife finds a good thing, And obtains favor from the LORD”, Based on this scripture, I applied the same principal. I prayed for a wife by faith then put that faith to work in finding my beautiful bride. I had to pray with my eyes opened, searching scriptures to know what was acceptable in God’s word and when I did, I prayed for God’s will to either keep the door open or shut it. Had I just sat down, prayed by faith and done nothing, I would not be married today. I have so many testimonies that came about through the same principal. What I’m I saying, God has graciously given us something to work with, given us freedom within the guidelines of His word. Now we begin to operate within the guidelines by faith. All these have one thing in common, they came about that God may be glorified.

vs.26 “For as the body without the spirit is dead, so FAITH without WORKS is dead also..”. How best can we now understand this verse, if the body had the spirit to give it life and the body did not move, then it will be hard to see the spirit at work but when we see the body moving, we know it’s not by it’s own strength and ability but by the spirit inside of it that gives it life. The same would now apply to works which reveals it’s fuel, faith. I can also say “it’s not works that drives faith, it’s faith that drives works, see the difference?”. What have you believed God for through prayer, inline with His word, had faith and did nothing beyond that faith? I know that God deals with people differently, but I would have not known His will for my life had I not put my faith to work.

Thanks
Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Due to weather conditions, the devotion is coming in late, be blessed Ev

For “whoever calls on the name of the LORD shall be saved.” 14 How then shall they call on Him in whom they have not believed? And how shall they believe in Him of whom they have not heard? And how shall they hear without a preacher? 15 And how shall they preach unless they are sent? As it is written: “How beautiful are the feet of those who 2preach the gospel of peace, Who bring glad tidings of good things!” 16 But they have not all obeyed the gospel. For Isaiah says, “LORD, who has believed our report?” 17 So then faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the word of God. (Romans 10:14 – 17)

MOTIVATED – Are you motivated to share your faith?  It has been said that most Christians seem as if they have taken a vow a silence when it comes to sharing their faith.  For “whoever calls  on the name of the LORD shall be saved.” Anyone, your friends, your family, your loved once and even strangers can call upon the name of the Lord and God will save them.  WOW!  Paul also writes. “the Lord Jesus shall be revealed from heaven with his mighty angels, 8 In flaming fire taking vengeance on them that know not God, and that obey not the gospel of our Lord Jesus Christ: 9 Who shall be punished with everlasting destruction from the presence of the Lord, and from the glory of his power.”  If you share your faith, the worst that can happen to you is that you will be rejected.  However the worst thing that could happen to an unsaved person is that they will spend eternity in hell.  Who has thing worse?  Get motivated by reading your Bible and praying for laborers to reach the unsaved!  How can they HEAR until YOU are sent (unless you GO)!  Are you feet beautiful to the Lord because they are motivated to GO in obedience to His call?

MESSAGE – What is the message that you speak to others when sharing your faith?  Do you tell them that God has a wonderful plan for their lives?  Would you have told that to those about to perish in the twin tower when NYC was attacked?  Do you tell people that they need to come to Jesus because He is better then sex, drugs, and music? Sinners (unsaved people) need the right motive to come to Christ.

They need to repent of breaking God’s Law (The Ten Commandments) and put their trust in Jesus Christ.  Showing sinners that they have violated God perfect standards, the Ten Commandments, and helping them to see they will face a holy God on Judgment Day when they die, is the biblical reason a sinner should flee to the Savior.  Preach the gospel of peace after people realize that they don’t have the peace of God because of their wicked works.  People need to hear the Word of God. Will they hear it from you?

MESSENGER – You are a faithful messenger?  Paul writes, “Now then, we are AMBASSADORS FOR CHRIST, as though God were PLEADING through us: we implore you on Christ’s behalf, be reconciled to God. Are you being a credible messenger by reading God’s Word, growing in holiness, and seeking the Lord?

Examine your motivation to preach the gospel.  Check the message you are preaching.  Is the message biblical, is it what Jesus preached? If not, reject it, and begin to preach repentance for the remission of sin.  How is your life as a messenger?  Paul wrote examine yourself to see whether you’re in the faith.  If Paul examined himself should we do any less?  May you be a motivated messenger preaching a biblical message!

Until the nets are filled…
Blessings,
Pastor Phil <><

You brought a smile to this soul when I was born
Cheered me up in gladness for the prize I’d won
You held your head up high while I did the home run
Your loving embrace moved me, when I felt so worn

When I was down to nothing in life, you held me up

You scold me knowing very well you love me still

You throw up a smile as you sail through the storms
Sparkle a glimmer of hope when the wind blows along

Good morning,

James 2:14-26, vs. 24, You see then that a man is JUSTIFIED by works, and not by faith only. vs.26 “For as the body without the spirit is dead, so FAITH without WORKS is dead also..”

There can be a dilemma in understanding Faith and works from Paul and James’ teaching. Paul taught being “justified by faith alone” and here comes James teaching being “justified by faith and works”. We would stand and wonder which is which, are we “justified by faith alone” or are we “justified by faith and works”?. We need to understand what levels both of these men of God placed faith to silence what someone may have thought as contradiction in the bible.

To the Romans Paul writes, “So we are made right (Justified) with God through faith and not by obeying the law (NLT) Romans 3:28”. If you read the accounts of Paul’s writings in reference to being “justified by faith alone”, you will learn this was in reference to salvation (ROOT), the beginning of a Christian life. Galatians 2:16, “knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law but by faith in Jesus Christ, even we have believed in Christ Jesus, that we might be justified by faith in Christ and not by the works of the law; for by the works of the law no flesh shall be justified”, in other words, there is nothing you can do of yourself to be saved. If we were to be saved by the deeds of the law (keeping the 10 commandments), then Christ going to the cross was in vain. Many religions teach getting to heaven by works and whenever I witness to people, I constantly hear them talk about their good works getting them into heaven. For our beginning, getting saved, the root of a Christian is based on Faith ALONE in Jesus Christ for our eternal salvation.

Where does the faith by works fall in place according to James? This is in reference to already born again Christian bearing FRUIT. The evidence of faith in you will be seen by how you bear fruit. What Paul taught was the foundation which no man can lay but Jesus Christ, what James is teaching is building the walls on what is already established. James is talking about practical living which is necessary in the life of a believer. From my own experience as a Christian, if I did not add works to my faith, I would be stagnant. There are some who would like to have faith and then sit and do nothing about it. They are not willing to put wheels to their faith and see what direction God would direct them. Some are waiting for the Lord to audibly speak to them before they can act on something by faith. I am like David who faced Goliath by faith and added works to which God commended him for. The bible says in Proverbs 10:32, “the lips of the righteous knows what is acceptable”. What is acceptable is stated clearly in the manual book the BIBLE.

Read how James is applying what is acceptable James 2:14 “What does it profit, my brethren, if someone says he has faith but does not have works? Can faith save him? 15 If a brother or sister is naked and destitute of daily food, 16 and one of you says to them, “Depart in peace, be warmed and filled,” but you do not give them the things which are needed for the body, what does it profit”. How can I apply this to my faith and works, if I was in a position to meet a brother’s needed, I could pray that God provides for him by faith. Then the Lord would show me how He has already provided for my brother through me. With that, when I meet that need by faith, I can trust God to replenish what I gave out at this time another time. I know we have faith, do we have works to accompany faith?

To continue.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: I Will Give You Rest, by Sarah Susan

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Matthew 11:28, “Come to me, all ye, heavy laden and I will give you rest”

In today’s  scenario, no one likes to meet any person, who is heavy laden or to help any such person or spend time with  people who are very tensed, depressed or anxious for various reasons. But our dear Lord invites such people who have heavy burdens, whatever the reason may be. Not only, it is an invitation of warm welcome followed by the assurance of PERFECT REST. 1Peter 5:7, says “Cast your burden on the Lord because He cares for you”  Yes God is bearing our burden and that too,  gladly… For instance, a young child getting back from school with a very heavy bag , unable to carry it..  His/her mother or father will immediately run to the child and definitely take the heavy bag and give the child some relief ..Why ? The primary  reason is love …Yes, the love of the parents towards their children …This is a shadow of God’s love. Compared to the AGAPE love which is of God, even our earthly fathers falls short of His love.

One time I woke up only to remember the pressures I was to face during one particular day at office. I had auditors visiting and God strengthened me with this verse  “Praise be to the Lord, to God, our SAVIOR , who daily bears our burdens” ..I immediately gathered courage for the day, miraculously witnessed God bringing me out of this particular situation and every other. I praised God further for strengthening  my faith to believe that He loves me and gladly bears my  daily burdens…

What a blessing it is to be with the Lord who bears our burdens, who loves to listen to us, and also gives us rest despite attacks from Satan /enemies /troubles/ fears/ shocks/day today worries or whatever it is

Psalms 91 says “He who dwells in the shelter of the Most High will REST in the shadow of the Almighty” . What is a dwelling ? its a place where one lives/stays/resides/abides.  Any person on earth goes home after the days’ work …generally ,a person loves to get back to his house/dwelling as often as possible , as early as possible..  Now let us meditate on God Himself being our dwelling ..

If we love our earthly dwelling, which is quite  temporary, then how much more are we to love our heavenly, permanent dwelling -our temple Himself ?   Do we love to stay in Him, reside in Him, abide in Him consistently and continuously? Not just for a season, or time period for a gain or a favor  but forever and ever …If we are inclined to spend time with Him, then we can be assured of His rest.. David states that He loves to stay in the temple of the Lord forever and ever. Yes, let us love to abide in Him and continue in Him so that we can enjoy the rest in His bosom for ever and ever… Let us all eagerly wait for the day when we , all will be in His loving fold, God Himself wiping our tears from our eyes, and providing us REST for eternity… ,
Sarah Susan

title.rendered: Who Craves Your Spirit – Part 3 By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good Morning!

“And I will come down and talk with thee there: and I will take of the spirit which is upon thee, and will put it upon them; and they shall bear the burden of the people with thee, that thou bear it not thyself alone. ﻿(Num 11:17)

What comes to mind when you hear the word burden?  Perhaps your job, you family situation, a medical condition, recent news, responsibilities, etc….  Moses found himself with a heavy burden upon him as the children of Israel were crying and complaining that they had no meat to eat.  Now they did have fresh manna each morning, but they were chocking on their blessing with their attitude. Here is what Moses said to God (11-15):

 “He asked the LORD, “Why have you brought this trouble on your servant? What have I done to displease you that you put the burden of all these people on me? Did I conceive all these people? Did I give them birth? Why do you tell me to carry them in my arms, as a nurse carries an infant, to the land you promised on oath to their forefathers? Where can I get meat for all these people? They keep wailing to me, ‘Give us meat to eat!’ I cannot carry all these people by myself; the burden is too heavy for me.  If this is how you are going to treat me, put me to death right now—if I have found favor in your eyes—and do not let me face my own ruin.”

Despite the fact that Moses felt that the burden was too heavy for him, God doesn’t tell Moses that He will remove the burden from Moses’ shoulders.  Instead God is going to share the burden and take some of the weight of the burden off Moses shoulders.  God summons Moses and, “The LORD said to Moses: “Bring me seventy of Israel’s elders who are known to you as leaders and officials among the people. Have them come to the Tent of Meeting, that they may stand there with you. I will come down and speak with you there, and I will take of the Spirit that is on you and put the Spirit on them. They will help you carry the burden of the people so that you will not have to carry it alone.”

God knew that Moses’ had the right spirit for the task at hand, but that Moses’ spirit needed to be upon others if Moses was going to last in the long hall and not burn out.  Moses wanted the Lord to actually take his life – he wanted to die!  The spirit that was upon Moses was the Spirit of God fleshed out in the life of Moses.  By God’s Spirit Moses applied his faith and defied the Pharaoh, called down plagues, opened the Red Sea and went through it on dry ground.  This was the spirit that God would place upon others to preserve His servant Moses.  Elijah’s spirit rested upon Elisha, and now Moses’ spirit would rest upon the seventy.  Just as the proof of Elisha have Elijah’s spirit upon him shown in the parting of the Jordan, Moses spirit upon the seventy would be manifested in their prophesying. 

God saw fit to take Moses’ spirit and place it upon others to accomplish His work.  Would God take your spirit and place it upon others?  What kind of spirit do you have?  Perhaps you’ve not defied a Pharaoh, or parted a sea, but there are some things perhaps that you have done by the hand of God that have been amazing.  This whole thing as well is the process of discipleship, ones spirit being imparted by the Lord upon another.  Allow God to work on your spirit that he may place it upon others.

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: Who Craves Your Spirit – Part 2 By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good Morning,

“The company of the prophets from Jericho, who were watching, said, “The spirit of Elijah is resting on Elisha.” And they went to meet him and bowed to the ground before him. (2 Kings 2:15)

Elisha was like the vice-present prophet in the days of Elijah.  He was chosen by Elijah, and through the time spent together craved the spirit that was upon Elijah.  Before being taken up in a chariot of fire by a whirlwind of God, Elijah asked to Elisha, “Tell me, what can I do for you before I am taken from you?” To which Elisha replied, “Let me inherit a double portion of your spirit.”  Elisha didn’t want a material possession of Elisha.  He wanted that which can only come through impartation, Elijah’s spirit. 

Elijah has just been taken up by God, and Elisha “picked up the cloak that had fallen from Elijah and went back and stood on the bank of the Jordan.  Then he took the cloak that had fallen from him and struck the water with it. “Where now is the LORD, the God of Elijah?” he asked. When he struck the water, it divided to the right and to the left, and he crossed over.  WOW!  He wanted to know if God was going to be with him, in the power that God was with Elijah.  He craved Elijah’s spirit and wanted to know if he had received the double portion that he desired.  He had a cloak in is hand (tangible), but did he have the spirit (intangible)?  At one time Elijah had placed the cloak upon Elisha when he first chose Elisha to follow him as his disciple (1 Kings 19:19-21).  The cloak (mantle) was once placed symbolically upon him, but now it would be upon him permanently.

Elisha retraces the steps of his master and goes back to the Jordan to perform the exact same miracle that Elijah had done by parting the waters of the Jordan (2 Kings 2:8).  He strikes the water with the cloak and the water divided.  Then the company of prophets who were watching said, “THE SPIRIT OF ELIJAH IS RESTING UPON ELISHA.  And they went to meet him and BOWED TO THE GROUND.”  Elisha wasn’t trying to make a spectacle of himself, he was just exercising by faith the “proof” of the spirit that was upon him by putting his faith to the test.  If the spirit was truly upon him, it would be evident.  Elisha didn’t brag or boast, he simply asked and believed.  The impartation was clearly recognizable to the prophets that knew Elijah.  They bowed in reverence to the chief prophet Elisha.

  •  
    1. Whose spirit do you have upon you?  Are there things in you good or bad that you have received from someone else imparting into you.  Do you like that character that you currently have?

    • 2.      Whose spirit do others recognize to be upon you?  Is that spirit godly?   If the spirit upon your “Elijah” was godly, then the spirit imparted should reflect their spirit in you.  The phrase “I am with you in spirit,” certainly has some truth to it.  Just be wise as to the spirit that is upon you.

    3.      Who are you imparting your spirit to?  Is there someone that is craving the spirit

that is upon your life.  The greatest form of emulation is imitation.  Who is imitating you, a child, a friend, a student, a co-worker, a disciple of your, ect…?

Until the nets are filled….
Blessings,
Phil <><

title.rendered: The Spirit God Craves by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good Morning!

“But because my servant Caleb has a different spirit and follows me wholeheartedly, I will bring him into the land he went to, and his descendants will inherit it.”  (Numbers 14:24)

“I have come to make a difference.  I’ve said it, now I’m here to represent it.”  This quote comes concerning his mission.  This person is Evans Olang.  When I first met Evans, it was his spirit that stood out to me.  We would all gather for early morning prayer and everyone would be seeking God, and then I couldn’t help follow this voice of this prayer warrior which led me to see a skinny man storming heaven in prayer on his face between two pew chairs.  It was this spirit that Evans had, that made me say, I need that kind of prayer intensity in my life.  Although the room had many people praying in the same place, he had a different spirit about him and that stood out.

God singled out Caleb and said “…my servant Caleb has a different spirit and follows me wholeheartedly…”  There were many people in Moses camp, what was it that caused God to acclaim his servant Caleb as such?

“Then Caleb silenced the people before Moses and said, “We should go up and take possession of the land, for we can certainly do it.”  (Numbers 13:30)

  •  

    1. A man of leadership

How did Caleb silence the people before Moses?  I can see calling the people to order, but Caleb had a spirit that caused people to listen when he spoke.  John Maxwell often says, leadership is influence, and Caleb certainly displayed that.  When you speak do others listen?

    2.        A man of vision

When Moses sent out twelve spies to spy out the land and two different reports were brought back.  Caleb and Joshua’s report was to go up and take the land, because they felt that it was an opportunity that could be accomplished.  They saw that their Israelites could advance their territory.  It’s interesting that many do not seem to remember the names of those that brought back the bad report.  Do you have vision?

    3.      A man of favor

Caleb had God’s favor because he was obedient to God.  It was God Himself that said “my servant Caleb…follows me wholeheartedly…”  Caleb wanted to please God, and it was recognized for it.  God didn’t say everyone followed Him wholeheartedly, only Caleb.  How has your following been lately?

Until the nets are filled…
Blessings,
Pastor Phil <><

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Hope you are all doing well. This week, most of the devotions will be sent out by France Poindujour in my absence (vacation). Tuesday marks our 5th anniversary. Today’s devo comes to us by one of our devotion team members, Sarah, be blessed, stay blessed. Ev

Ephesians 5  : 23 “Christ is the head of the church , his body”, I Corinthians 12 : 12-31 “The body is  a unit, though it is made of many parts; and though its parts are many, they form one body”

Let us think of our human body… Head and then other parts of the body….all in order…well placed..well designed. well arranged by our Creator …each organ for a specific purpose …

1. Christ Himself is the Head . Church represents the body. Members of the church are all organs of the same body.  Entire body has to accept the directions,  instructions and commands delivered by the head (infact , the brain in it) . Any idea generated by the head has to be accepted and implemented by the body.  If not, they cannot get synchronized. It’s also placed on the top, a symbol of superiority and leadership . Do we have God as the Lord  of our life /church ?

2. Different organs of the body, All organs are put in place by our maker to do different functions but for a common purpose, sustenance and growth of the body .We all are meant to do different functions prepared for us. It is not for someone to look down upon another for doing a work of less honor.

3. Connection between body and the head –  The body cannot function properly if both head and body are not together. There is no life, in fact.   Whatever thought is generated in the head(brain) has to be obeyed by the body and  then implemented. There is no second thought to this.  Head is the source or origin of thoughts. Each and every organ of the body be it a nail or a toe, has to obey the commands of he head. Now,  are we all  under total control of our head, Christ ?

4. Connection between parts of the body- All the parts of the body are closely knit or may be well knit. Some parts may be less honorable,some may be less important but some may be very important and some in a honorable position…But there should be a feeling of BELONGINGNESSirrespective of the status/ position/condition in the church… Do we have this sort of feeling?

5. Unity – There should be complete unity in the church. If one part of the body is injured, the entire body feels the effect of that injury and treatment takes places to bring healing to the part injured. Yes  , in the similar way, we ought to treat all our fellow members in the church with due respect that we all form parts of the same body created for the glory of God.

Paul writes to Thessalonians  in I Thessalonians 4 :9-10 “And in fact you do love ALL the brothers throughout Macedonia” Irrespective of differences, they loved everyone. Do we similarly care for our fellow beings if they are in need/pain/suffering/disease ?
God the Father desires to see this body grow into maturity , into His image/His likeness.. Shall we all pray that this mighty army – the body  closely knit with Christ as the leader, march victoriously to meet the Lord in the air….! Blessings Sarah.

title.rendered: What is required to be inspired? Compiled By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

We’ve all experienced preachers and politicians showing to be inspirational and charismatic in their sermons, speeches, and writings.
However, just because one tells you something that sounds good, does that mean it is good?  A fish may find a hook in its mouth simply by attempting to eat the bait.

Before I continue the devotional series “Does God Have a Need”, I am going to share and define some theological terms which will be of great assistance in your spiritual journey of reading the Scriptures and even listening to preachers.

There is a theological term called Anthropomorphisms which are words describing God using terms applying to humans.  Although God is Spirit, he is described in Scripture in human terms as having bodily parts (arm; ear; eye; face; finger; foot; hand; head; heart; nose; right hand).
Human actions are also attributed to him: he has a voice and speaks and answers, and he walks, rides, takes away, and goes out. He looks (to overlay, spy) to see things and hides his face.  He also experiences pleasure (desire) and savors the smell of acceptable sacrifices.

The term eisegesis [ahy-si-jee-sis] is an interpretation, esp. of Scripture, that expresses the interpreter’s own ideas, bias, or the like, rather than the meaning of the text. Hence when one reads Scripture, one may filter the text through oneself, the culture one lives in, the values or lack of one holds, one’s upbringing, etc…. 

The proper method of interpreting Scripture is to use exegesis which is allowing the Scripture to interprets itself through proper hermeneutical study.  Norman Geisler shares four stages of biblical interpretation:

Observation – What do I observe in the test Interpretation – What is the author trying to convey Evaluation – What does the passage signify in today’s culture Application – What does God want me to do to apply this to my life in a practical way? 

Hence eisegesis (reading into the text), is not legitimate exegesis (reading out of the text).

The question of how to interpret the Bible is not a minor issue. It is, in a sense, one of the battlegrounds for our souls. If Satan had a list of what he does not want us to do, Bible study would be at the top, along with evangelism, prayer and worship. Through study of Scripture we learn who Jesus is and are enabled to become like Him. How can we become like Him, if we do not know what He is like? Devotional studies are important, but they must result from a serious study of Scripture. The apostle Paul prayed that the Colossians might be “filled with the knowledge of His will in all wisdom and spiritual understanding” (Col.
1:9).  This is the reason why Evans and I try to stick closely to bring you theologically sound devotions and give you healthy food so you can grow thereby to become more like Jesus Christ in every facet of your life.

Be like the Bereans who when Paul preached “…received the word with all readiness of mind, and searched the scriptures daily, whether those things were so.”

Good morning,

2Corinthians 1:3Praise be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of compassion and the God of all comfort, 4who comforts us in all our troubles, so that we can comfort those in any trouble with the comfort we ourselves have received from God” (NIV)

If you are anything like me, the prayer I want to make when in trouble “Lord get me out of this” and there is nothing wrong with prayer of deliverance. It’s a good testimony when you stand and testify of how God brought you out. I would like to develop another testimony not on how the Lord brought us out but how the Lord made us comfortable in the midst of the storm, in the lions den (Daniel), in the furnace of fire (Shadrack, Meshack and Abednego), in prison (Paul, Silas, Peter). What these men had in common was that at one point they were faced by a trial and they found themselves in places of destruction but instead of the Lord changing their situation, He made them comfortable in the midst of their trials for He was in control of their destiny. How do I know they were comfortable in their trials, I don’t hear them crying and screaming to be let out of their trials, do you?.

Paul begins by praising God because He deserves all the praises, then He talks about His attribute relevant to this message. He says, “3Praise be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ”. If in trouble, can you gather strength and begin to praise and not complaint? Praise be to God, what wonderful God He is, Mighty, Glorious, Sovereign, He knows all things and can do all things. This alone should be enough to make us comfortable in the storm because thinking about who He is and talking about Him eliminates all the fear and doubt and we begin to get comfortable because we know He is bigger than the situation and He has all things under control. “He is the father of compassion and the God of ALL comfort”. You might think that being in trouble shows that He cares not but the truth of the matter is, He cares more than we could imagine or think, the men I mentioned above did know, the whole reason they could be comfortable. They knew God cared and that there was something bigger than the their trials God was going to accomplish. Then Paul says, “He is the God of ALL Comfort” which if may use these words would mean a feeling of freedom from worry or disappointment, the opposite of what the world teaches

Think of Daniel who was thrown in the lions den because he was doing what was right in the eyes of God. While the king who according to his command had Daniel thrown in the den was troubled and loosing his sleep, Daniel on the other hand I believe was laying his head on the lions falling a sleep peacefully, he says “My God sent His angel and shut the lions’ mouths, so that they have not hurt me, because I was found innocent before Him; “. What of his testimony could have been bigger, being delivered from the den or sleeping comfortably in the lions den? See the Lord did not get rid of the situation (lions), His sent His angels for comfort then shut the lions mouth. It will be safe to say, he might have not been in a hurry to cry for deliverance in the den. Mark this, I’m not saying he was happy to be in the den, I’m saying, he was comfortable in the den. To break Comfortable into two words “COMFORT” and “ABLE”, I can be anxious free knowing His grace is sufficient for me, and He is able to deliver me. Those two perfects the word comfortable to which I need right in the middle of trials. Can trust God to make us comfortable in the trials so that we don’t loose our testimony, composure, joy, faith simply because He is the God of all comfort and He has sent His comfort to make us comfortable in the midst of the trials. By this you can comfort many who come your way.

Thanks,
Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Psalm 118:17, “I shall not die, but live, And declare the works of the LORD”

A question once asked, “Why are we here on earth?”, someone responded, “to live this life to the fullest”. I wouldn’t say that is the reason why we are here primarily, that is what we do while we are here. God designed the earth, populated it and finally created man to fit into what He had created. God being a God of order did not create man on the first day. And when He created man, He had a plan and purpose for his life, to glorify Him. No one is here by accident but by the divine will of God. The question then you ask yourself, “if I am here, why I’m I here and how long am I going to be here? Until what He had planned for me is fulfilled.

Acts 14, Paul had been moving from city to city preaching the gospel. Many believed on the name of the Lord Jesus and got saved but there  were some Jews who stirred up strife trying to confuse some of the Gentiles that believed. When this wasn’t working as fast as they wanted it to work, they had an idea to get rid of Paul. One time they tried to stone him and Barnabas. When they learnt about it, they escaped from Iconium to Lystra and Derbe but later they were followed there. Acts 14:19, “Then some Jews came from Antioch and Iconium and won the crowd over. They stoned Paul and dragged him outside the city, thinking he was dead. 20, “But after the disciples had gathered around him, he got up and went back into the city (NIV). How would you react if you learnt that what God wanted you to accomplish was in jeopardy?

The life you held dear is threatened by challenges of life. You make an tempt to progress yet there is such a great opposition from people and situations, words stoning you, frustrations and fears stoning you. Paul was preaching GOOD NEWS, that did not exempt him from being stoned then left for dead butt there was something God had invested
and deposited in Paul that was not ready to be terminated yet. It looked like he was going down the drain, his life in danger, few friends and more enemies, not wanted in cities but his mission was not complete. When we understand what God has called us to do, come high water and hell, saints might be shaken but none of it will terminate the work God has started. Jesus was almost stoned to death, nothing could happen to Him because His time had not come. Paul’s time had not come, therefore the stones couldn’t kill him. When they dragged him out of the city supposing he was dead, he picked himself up and went back into the city. “I AM STILL HERE”, you or anyone will not destroy what God has started, He finishes what He has started, Philippians 1:6, “being confident of this very thing, that He who has begun a good work in you will complete it until the day of Jesus Christ”. Are you glad you are still here regardless of what you went through in your childhood and the last few painful episodes in your life?.

Psalm 118:17, “I shall not die, but live, And declare the works of the LORD”, This scripture is for those like Paul who know the calling and the destiny in their lives. What you know about God in you will cause you to look the situation in the eye and say, “I shall not die, but live”, my faith in God will not die, my hope, my vision, my desire, my calling, my spirit, my destiny, my dreams will not die. I may be bruised and limp but the fact that I can still see these things at distance will keep me alive. You live because God started something in you. Pick yourself up where the enemy has left you to die, wipe off the dust, go back to the city and let the enemy know, “YOU ARE STILL HERE”, That is your testimony, “God is still on the throne. 2 Timothy 1:12, “For this reason I also suffer these things; nevertheless I am not ashamed, for I know whom I have believed and am persuaded that He is able to keep what I have committed to Him until that Day”. title.rendered: Moved By Feelings Not By Situations, Part 4

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Mark 9:14-29,”…But if You can do anything, have compassion on us and help us”

To conclude, let’s see the man’s faith and Jesus power did.

Mark 9:25, “… He rebuked the unclean spirit, saying to it, “Deaf and dumb spirit, I command you to come out of him and enter him no more!. There are some things you can ask to leave but anything that is terrorizing you and I have to be commanded to leave. The enemy cannot be begged to leave, he has to be commanded. Jesus rebuked and commanded now rebuke is to turn back or keep down which makes me believe we got to send back the enemy’s package delivered. We got to tell him he delivered the package to the wrong guy, we got to command him which means use some force to send back all the bitterness, offences, jealousy, pride, arrogance and all the junk that comes from him. Print a label on the package, “RETURN TO SENDER”, Don’t hold on to a package that will explode on your face. Jesus is sending the package of deaf and dumb spirit back to where they came from. Watch this in vs. 26, “Then the spirit cried out, convulsed him greatly, and came out of him”, the command was so strong that all the junk began to terrorize the young boy for the last time as they gathered all their belongings to leave. There are some things that don’t leave without a fight, the bible says in 2Corinthians 10:4, “the weapons of our warfare are not carnal but mighty through God to the pulling down of strongholds”. The things that were in this boy were strong holds. See no word shall return void that proceeds from the mouth of Lord. Jesus had spoken, the unclean spirits had no choice but to leave and the young boy had no choice but to be free.

“And when the unclean spirits left, he became as one dead and so many said, “he is dead”, I thought Jesus did it? how come the child looks dead, the people around him have already passed the judgment that he is dead, I don’t know what the father of the child might have felt at that moment for as long as he was being terrorized at least he was a live now he is dead? Hold on! Phil 1:6, “Be confident in this very thing, that He which hath began a good work in you will perform it until the day of Jesus Christ”. What people thought and what looked like did not intimidate Jesus. He might have been the only one with a different look at things yet he was not moved by what people thought. He knew that what He had started, He was able to complete it. Do not be intimidated when you have believed God for something and it looks like it’s not going as desired and everyone around you is telling you not to believe in the Jesus stuff.  Linger longer, watch again, the process is not complete, something to ponder on, When did you ever hear that Jesus FAILED?

Mark 9:27, “but Jesus took him by the hand and lifted him up, and he arose”, AMEN, AMEN. Is the Lord wonderful or what? He did not touch this boy from the beginning, even at the time of rebuking the spirit. But when everyone thought he was dead, He reached out and took him by the hands and lifted him up. His complete restoration came as a result of Him touching him and raising him. Isn’t it amazing to see that the Lord is out to raise His people and not leave them down, how about His touch, He is not just interested in speaking victories our lives, He is also interested in touching us, raising us up.

I got to stop for this is just too good, a father’s son is restored, his faith is boosted even more, his son is healed, has a sound mind and the best thing that could ever happen to both is encountering with the Savior and the Lord. In conclusion, if Jesus was not moved by your past situation and the present condition of this boy, and then He was not intimidated by the request of the father when the disciples could not do it and finally He is not intimidated by the comments from the crowd saying that the child is dead, why not begin to trust Him with your past, present and future for He is the same yesterday, today and forever more He changes. He is moved by your feelings and not intimidated by your situations.

Thanks

title.rendered: Moved By Feelings And Not By Situations, Part 3

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Mark 9:14-29,”…But if You can do anything, have compassion on us and help us”

A father had faith for his child to be healed when he brought him to Jesus disciples and when they could not do anything and looking at the condition of his son and how worse it was getting and again looking at how the spirits were terrorizing this boy even in the presence of Jesus, his faith must have dropped from believing that it can be done to maybe it can be done for he says “But if You can do anything have compassion on us and help us”, the word “IF” sounded like a doubt in Jesus’ ability to heal. If you doubt someone’s ability, then how will you have faith in them? “WHEN” is the word of assurance, that is the word of faith this father needed. He needs help for his son, but he also needs help to believe that it can be done. My prayer is that we will take our faith of “IF” and move it to “WHEN” for that is where the Lord would have us put our faith. He can do it period, it’s just a matter of WHEN. The bible says that, “He makes all things beautiful in His time”

Mark 9:23, “Jesus said to him, “If you can believe, all things are possible to him who believes”, The Lord’s power mixed with our faith produces victory. I don’t know how one can receive something if they don’t believe that the one they are coming to has the capability of doing it. See the Lord is telling him that all he has to do is believe, not analyze, try and see what is around that can be used to make it happen. Your job and my job is to believe that is all the Lord requires of us, then He will take care of the rest. All things are possible to him that believes, to confirm this, many times when Jesus reached out to people, what did He say? “Your faith has made thee whole” It’s our faith in God that makes all things possible. Hebrews 11:1, “Now faith is the substance of things hoped for the evidence of things not seen”, we all hope for something from the Lord that hasn’t been revealed yet and we haven’t seen it, yet but we are trusting and believing that with time it will come. What people hope for, they look forward to receiving it as opposed to someone who is not sure. However big or small the thing you hope just remember that the size does not intimidate Jesus for there is nothing too difficult for Him. Jesus may ask you to push a huge rock but that does not mean He expects you to move it.

Mark 9:24, “Immediately the father of the child cried out and said with tears, “Lord, I believe; help my unbelief” ,  NIV translation puts the last portion this way “I do believe; help me overcome my unbelief”, this line sounds confusing for one instant he says he believes and then says help my unbelief. He believed the healing could happen at the same time he was not so sure to what extent. He also believes it could  happen but he was not as calm as Jesus and so his prayer was that Jesus would boost his faith to the level of His, to see things the way Jesus did. I have the faith in God to know that He can, now I need my faith to be elevated to a greater level where I can be calm about it, no be intimidated by situation any more for I have faith that negates the facts. If you have unbelief, ask the Lord to help you overcome it for whatever you requested of Him is already settled now faith is the vehicle the Lord will use to bring it to pass. Can you see how this father is so open to admit his weak faith and asking for help? his admission and seeking resulted to something greater than what he had before meeting Jesus. Faith established not just for today’s miracle but even greater things to come.

I can now see why Jesus was not too quick to heal the boy till he
established faith in his father. So don’t freak out when what you
prayed for is delayed, you could still be in “Faith Class”
being prepared for something bigger than the current situation. The
current situation is a faith booster, it’s an eye opener. It also
teaches you that Jesus cares that is why He is moved by our feelings

title.rendered: Building Trust for Trials on the Horizon, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning and happy Valentines Day!

“Then the LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying, 9 “When Pharaoh speaks to you, saying, ‘Show a miracle for yourselves,’ then you shall say to Aaron, ‘Take your rod and cast it before Pharaoh, and let it become a serpent.’ ” 10 So Moses and Aaron went in
to Pharaoh, and they did so, just as the LORD commanded. And Aaron cast down his rod before Pharaoh and before his servants, and it became a serpent.  (Exodus 7:8 – 10)

How does one come to trust someone in the midst of trials?  Who do you know you can go to when you must do something that causes you to become uneasy about the possible outcomes?  Perhaps you turn to a spouse, a best friend, a co-worker, a parent, grandparent, or a sibling.   Do you believe God to be trustworthy?  Let’s look to Moses to discover what Moses discovered about how God builds trust for trials on the horizon. 

Moses was called by God to be Israel’s deliverer.  Surly God could
easily destroy all the Egyptians, just as he killed the firstborn son
of the Egyptians when sending the tenth plague.  However, like many
times, God chooses to send a man to display the His power

In the desert God commanded Moses to throw down his staff.  What did Moses have to loose, he didn’t know it was going to become a serpent.  Then God asked Moses to pick it up by the tail.  Now, perhaps Moses was not as quick to do so, after all what if he would have been bitten.  Yet Moses picks up the serpent by the tail showing his trust and it became a rod once again.  Soon after, Moses finds himself standing with his brother Aaron in front of the most powerful man in Egypt, the Pharaoh himself.  Now again God is asking for a rod to be cast down to allow it to become a serpent.  Moses did it alone before God, but could he instruct Aaron to do it before Pharaoh?  Moses obediently instructs, Aaron obeys, and the staff becomes a serpent before the Pharaoh.  The Pharaoh calls in his magi (sorcerers) and they duplicate the same miracle causing their thrown down staffs to become serpents.  However, Aaron’s rod (serpent) swallowed their rods (serpents).  “The loss of the magicians’ rods in this fashion gave evidence of the superiority of God’s power when Aaron’s rod gulped down theirs  (MacArthur).” From God in the desert to Pharaoh in the palace, why did God allow a “trial run” on this miracle and then perform it a second time?  Perhaps these reasons will shed some light.

Miracle of the rod before God

1. God allowed Moses to build trust in Him for trials on the horizon.
2. God showed Moses, if he could trust God in this miracle, He trust God in others.
3. God showed Moses, when he throws something down before God, God can change it! 

Miracle of the rod before Pharaoh
4. God showed Moses he could trust the Lord even when things look to be seemingly going in the wrong direction.
5. Rom 8:28 “And we know that all things work together for good to those who love God, to those who are the called according to His purpose.
6. Heb 11:27 “By faith he (Moses) forsook Egypt, not fearing the wrath of the king; for he endured as seeing Him who is invisible.

How is God trying to build up your trust to face trials on your horizons?  What is God asking you to trust him in and are you doing so?  Throw it down, and pick it up changed by God.

Thanks
Evans
